post.description:
OAuth2 Token Exchange Exchange an OAuth2 authorization or refresh token for an access token.

This endpoint is available on oauth.nitrado.net, not api.nitrado.net.

Please refer to the auth endpoint docs for more details on our OAuth2 provider.

This endpoint supports two different grant types: authorization_code and refresh_token.

It returns an access and refresh token. The access token is the one you actually use to access the API and is valid for one day. The refresh token is valid for one month and you can use it to explicitly request new tokens using the endpoint.

You typically call this endpoint with an authorization_code grant after your server-side application after redirected the user agent to the CreateAuthToken endpoint and received the callback.

refresh_token is only relevant if you use our provider to access a customer's account resources and store both access token and refresh code in your database.

For security reasons, access tokens expire within a relatively short time frame. Refresh tokens are longer-lived and allow you to generate a new access token as long as the refresh token is valid, but require the client_id.

Note that this replaces and thus invalidates both the current access token and the refresh code.

If the refresh code expires before you renew it, you'll lose access and the user will have to grant authorization again. The same applies if a user revoked your client's access in his account settings.

The refresh_token flow is irrelevant if you're only authenticating a user ("login with Nitrado")!

client_secret.description: Your OAuth Client secret (only necessary if you use the authorization_code grant type)

refresh_token.description: Your refresh token if you use grant_type "refresh_token".

code.description: Your auth code if you use grant_type "authorization_code".

get.description:
Interactively prompt the user for OAuth2 authorization. Nitrado provides a standards-compliant OAuth2 provider in order to authorize access to our customer's Nitrado accounts.

After authorization succeeded, the API redirects the user to the given redirect_uri with code and state as GET parameters.

This endpoint is available on oauth.nitrado.net, not api.nitrado.net.

We only implement the OAuth2 code flow (explicit flow). Please refer to the available literature on how to (securely) use OAuth2.

If you implement authentication ("login with Nitrado") in addition to authorization ("give me access to resources on a user's account"), please be aware of OAuth's shortcomings in that regard. The mere possession of a valid access token/access to the identity endpoint is not sufficient!

Every authentication must go through the auth endpoint. Only the act of successfully obtaining an access token and subsequently requesting the user info from the identify endpoint is sufficient proof of authentication.

It is extremely important to validate the state parameter! If you do not validate it, your application is vulnerable to a trivial CSRF account take-over attack.

These limitations are not specific to Nitrado, but inherently caused by the fact that OAuth2 is not - by and in itself - an authentication protocol (but an authorization protocol). The same concerns apply to any other 3rd party provider like Google or Facebook, so make sure that you apply the above to all external providers you integrate with.

Please read RFC 6819 ("OAuth 2.0 Threat Model and Security Considerations") for further information on OAuth 2.0 security.

In order to prevent accidental mis-use, we refuse to provide an access token unless a state parameter is supplied.

Our team is happy to help you with the details if you wish to integrate with us!

parameters.description: Redirect to this URL after a failed or successful auth grant flow (must exactly match one of the redirect URIs configured for your client)

parameters.name: scope
parameters.description:
A list with requested scopes (space separated). The user will be asked to authorized your client to access the scopes you requsted. If all you want is authentication ("login with Nitrado"), only the user_info scope is required and we do not recommend requesting any additional scopes beyond that.

The following scopes are supported:

  • user_info: Access to a user's basic account information (username, email address, ...)
  • service: Access to a customers's rented services.
  • service_order: Access to billing-related endpoints.
  • ssh_keys: Access to user's ssh public keys.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: Randomly generated string. Store this string in or otherwise tie it to your client's user session and validate that the state you get back with the redirect is identical. Otherwise, an attacker could trick a user into authenticating against his own client and then use the authorization code to gain access to yours.

It's really important that you keep this token secret and do not share it with other people.

post.description:
A sub token is a separate OAuth 2.0 access token generated from an existing token. It has no refresh token and will be invalidated if the parent token is invalidated. It is useful when you need a token that has fewer scopes, is limited to a single service or shorter expiry time.

The token can have less or the same scopes as the parent token. Also you can limit the lifetime of the sub token. A sub-token can be also pinned to a specific service_id if needed.

scope.description: A list with requested scopes (space separated).

expires_in.description: Time in seconds how long the sub-token should be valid.

Available status codes

Status Description
active The service is active and usable
installing The service is currently installing
suspended The service is suspended and can be reactivated
adminlocked The service is admin locked, please contact support

parameters.name: backlog
parameters.description: Offset from the current log tail, must be >= 0

schema.description: Offset from the current log tail, must be >= 0

parameters.name: count
parameters.description:
Number of messages to return, starting at the cursor position specified by backlog. -1 returns all messages and continuously streams any new ones.

Data is returned as a stream of server-sent events (SSE). The server closes the connection once count events have been sent or if the journal stream is interrupted. Clients should automatically reconnect, since we might implement a timeout in the future.

Each event contains a JSON-encoded log object. The JSON fields are identical to the ones returned by journalctl -o json. We return all available fields, so if your application directly logs to the journal using custom fields, they will be included.

Example event:

{   "_SYSTEMD_SLICE": "-.slice",   "_TRANSPORT": "syslog",   "_CAP_EFFECTIVE": "3fffffffff",   "SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER": "root",   "SYSLOG_FACILITY": 1,   "_BOOT_ID": "ba112dbd9bac47efbe202551fdae075d",   "MESSAGE": "Test log entry",   "_COMM": "logger",   "_AUDIT_SESSION": 1,   "_UID": 0,   "__CURSOR": "s=1c57a3404dd742debe7033bca9257d25;i=614[...]",   "_GID": 0,   "PRIORITY": 5,   "__REALTIME_TIMESTAMP": 1492713610.505739,   "_SYSTEMD_CGROUP": "/",   "_AUDIT_LOGINUID": 0,   "_MACHINE_ID": "0ca6c162296c497f9a6a71d41cd9c043",   "_PID": 9553,   "__MONOTONIC_TIMESTAMP": [     17469.767698,     "ba112dbd9bac47efbe202551fdae075d"   ],   "_SOURCE_REALTIME_TIMESTAMP": 1492713610.505238,   "_HOSTNAME": "cloud-dev" }

The different fields are documented in the systemd documentation: systemd.journal-fields

Examples

Get a live stream of all log messages including 20 lines of backlog (default):

/journal

Get a live stream without backlog:

/journal?backlog=0

Just get the last 10 messages without streaming:

/journal?backlog=10&count=10

Get the 20 backlog events backwards from a particular cursor. This is useful if you want to implement seamless scrolling in the backlog - by the time the user scrolls up, the numeric offset is no longer valid if new log entries appeared in the meantime. The cursor string is included as a JSON field.

/journal?backlog=20&count=20&cursor=s=1c57a3404dd742debe7033bca9257d25[...]

schema.description:

post.description:
Send a POSIX signal to the process(es) running in a unit.

Equivalent to systemctl kill --kill-who=<who> --signal=<signal> <unit>.

See the systemctl manpage for more details: https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemctl.html

who.description: Which process(es) to send the signal to. main only selects the main process (the one specified by MainPID), control the control process (the process, if any, that was directly invoked by systemd) and all any process in the cgroup.

signal.description: The POSIX signal to send. Defaults to 15 (SIGTERM), which invokes a clean shutdown. Other common choices are 9 (SIGKILL) or 2 (SIGINT). SIGINT is equivalent to pressing Ctrl-C in a terminal. SIGKILL immediately kills the process without running any signal handlers.

post.description:
Restart a unit. Equivalent to systemctl restart --no-block.

On restart, systemd always stops and then starts the unit. Some services implement a reload command (ExecReload) which is usually a better choice when it's present. For example, when you restart firewalld, it temporarily disables the firewall during the short period of time between stop and start.

Asynchronous event - returns immediately without waiting for job to complete. See start event for more details.

post.description:
Start a unit. Equivalent to systemctl start --no-block.

This API call is asynchronous and does not wait for the unit to complete startup. systemd is fully asynchronous - when you run systemctl restart ssh.service, what happens behind the scenes is that a job is dispatched and systemctl then synchronously listens on the D-Bus and waits for the job to complete.

Our API is asynchronous like the upstream systemd D-BUS API and returns the systemd job ID without waiting for the job to complete like systemctl --no-block.

A job may take an arbitrarily long time to complete. For example, for one-shot units, "started" means "completed" and the job will be running until the command has completed (which might take hours for things like backups, that you might want to trigger by means of a timer unit). If a job was already running for this unit, an error is returned unless replace is set to true, in which case the new job will replace the old one. If you're building a user interface or otherwise need to know the job result, you can either poll by repeatedly requesting the unit state or by asynchronously updating the UI state using the change feed (recommended).

Service management is inherently asynchronous - units may change state at any time. Please contact us if this doesn't fit your workflow.

See the systemd docs for details: https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/init.html

For long running jobs, you can list them via systemctl list-jobs.

get.description:
Status codes

Status Description
running The Server is running.
stopped The Server is stopped.
installing The Server is currently installing. This can take some minutes.
reinstalling The Server is currently re-installing. This can take some minutes.
flavour_change The Server is currently processing a up- or downgrade.
restoring The server is currently restoring a Backup. This can take some minutes.
error_fc A error while the up- or downgrade is occurred. The support has been informed.
error_delete A error while deleting the Server is occurred. The support has been informed.
error_install A error while installing the Server is occurred. The support has been informed.
error_reinstall A error while re-installing the Server is occurred. The support has been informed.

get.description:
Status codes

Status Description
started The Server is up and running.
stopped The Server is stopped.
stopping The Server is currently stopping.
restarting The Server is currently restarting. This can take some minutes.
suspended Will be returned if the server is suspended, which means it needs to be reactivated on the website.
guardian_locked If your services are guardian protected, you are currently outside of the allowed times.
gs_installation The server is currently performing a game switching action.
backup_restore A backup will be restored now.
backup_creation A new backup will be created now.
chunkfix The Server is running a Minecraft chunkfix.
overviewmap_render The Server is running a Minecraft Overview Map rendering.

List of possible gameserver types:

  • Gameserver
  • Gameserver_Basic
  • Gameserver_EPS

List of possible memory types:

  • Standard
  • Advanced
  • Professional
  • Ultimate

get.description: Return default settings for the current game installed on the service. The default settings are stored in groups, similar to the resulting array for the settings. This way the mapping between the settings and the default values can be made. The default value will be used to initially create the setting, if the user do not provide a initial value. This endpoint delivers the initial value, even if the setting is overwritten by the user. You can use this to create a diff between the actual settings and the defaults to determine the changes or provide a way to reset the setting back to the default value.

get.description: Return a list of player lists. The result depends of the capabilities of the game itself. The lists can be used to control permissions and other player related settings. If the game does not have this feature, an empty array will be returned, otherwise a list of strings, representing the names of the lists. The player_id_type gives the type of the player identifiers. This can be used to adjust the UI or validate user input.

get.description: List players on the server. The returned list contains an array of players with their ingame name and an ID. The given ID is always unique and should be used to identify the player. The player name itself is not unique and can be changed over time (changing name ingame). So always use the ID to identify the player. This ID can be an internal ID or some other kind of ID from the game. For minecraft, it is the Minecraft UUID, for other games it will be the Steam-ID or some other ID to get additional information for that player (avatar image, stats, ...). If the player ID can not be made public, it will be masked (type=internal).

post.summary: Apply for being whitelisted on a given server.
post.description:
Requests the current user to be whitelisted on a specific server based on their account connections and game accounts. At the moment only whitelisting based on Twitch and Steam is available for ARK on PC.

To become whitelisted, the following requirements must be fulfilled:  - The target service must exist, be a game server and must be in the state "active" - The owner of the service must have enabled whitelisting through a method (i.e. Twitch) - The current user must have their external account (Twitch) linked to their Nitrado account, and must have the     required OAuth scope ('user_read user_subscriptions' for Twitch) - The current user must have their game account (i.e. Steam) linked with their Nitrado account - The current user must fulfil the requirements set by the server owner (e.g. be following or subscribing on Twitch)

service_id.description: The ID for the service to be whitelisted on.
